awd_titl_txt: RAISE-TAQS: Room-Temperature Quantum Sensing and Computation using DNA-based Excitonic Circuits
awd_abstract_narration:
Moore's Law, the well-known observation that the number of transistors in silicon-based integrated circuits and personal computing devices doubles approximately every year, has ended. A major challenge for the next decade is to identify viable alternatives to traditional, silicon-based computing.  Such alternatives are needed to   meet the ever-increasing worldwide computational demands in almost all areas of life.  Quantum information processors may be one viable alternative to meet this demand.  By taking advantage of quantum mechanical phenomena, the computational power of quantum computers may exceed by orders of magnitude that of conventional, silicon-based integrated circuits. However, to date quantum information processing is required to operate at ultra-cold temperatures in highly isolated and protected environments. No viable quantum information processing platform exists that functions at room temperature or in wet condition.   If they did exist, such quantum systems could be used for tasks such as quantum-enhanced sensing. In this project, structured DNA circuits are used to construct quantum-based processing and sensing devices that operate at room temperature and in the liquid state. Foundational principles of DNA-based quantum sensing and signal processing devices are being established and applied to practical quantum information processing challenges to demonstrate viability of this revolutionary approach to address diverse societal computing needs. An interdisciplinary team of investigators from chemistry, biological engineering and materials science, and electrical engineering will pursue this transformative approach towards room-temperature information processors, and train the next-generation of interdisciplinary quantum computer scientists and engineers


 
Classical silicon-based computing has reached its limit for solving increasingly complex, resource-intensive computational challenges in diverse application areas. In contrast, quantum-based systems enable a myriad of possibilities for transformative technological advances in simulation, sensing, computation, and metrology by harnessing quantum mechanical phenomena. Through the unique physics of quantum mechanics, quantum systems process or exchange information that can surpass classical computing architectures and measure environmental variables with unprecedented sensitivity. However, deployment of quantum systems to diverse application arenas has been encumbered by the fragility of quantum states to the ever-present noisy thermal bath, thereby limiting the operation of current quantum devices to cryogenic temperatures. For this reason, fundamental investigations into new quantum information processing and sensing architectures are needed, particularly for the deployment of devices for room-temperature and biomedical applications. Here, novel quantum circuits are developed based on controlled excitonic states of biomolecular materials. The structural control and single-molecule addressability of highly programmable DNA nanostructures are leveraged together with synthetic dyes as an engineering platform for quantum-coherent excitonic systems. Controlling the positions and energies of distinct excitonic states using DNA-based scaffolds enables the integration of qubits into higher-order circuits to create multi-qubit systems and devices. Closely coupled theory and experiment are used to design and evaluate emergent qubit function. Novel, high-impact room-temperature quantum sensing and information processing devices are fabricated and characterized, with potential for integration into prototypical next-generation quantum technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Classical semiconductor computing, limited by the constraints of silicon transistors and the end of Moore's Law, falls short of addressing global computational demands in fields such as physics-based modeling, artificial intelligence, and biomedical sensing. Quantum computing holds the potential to revolutionize society by solving mathematical problems that far outstrip the capabilities of classical supercomputers. However, many quantum-bit (qubit) candidates require cryogenic temperatures, which are not scalable. Electrical excitations (excitons) are touted as room temperature qubit candidates. Molecular excitons already play a pivotal role in light harvesting and molecular electronics. Crucially, the host matrix controls exciton dynamics and properties. To address this material need, we leverage synthetic DNA as a quantum computing substrate for excitonic circuits. Our results and exciton control lay the groundwork to build room-temperature quantum sensing and computing systems.

To inform our designs, we designed excitonic circuits, consisting of multiple dyes in specific patterns. Such arbitrary structures may be programmably assembled by DNA vide infra. Key outcomes of this computation work were the design of NOT, Hadamard, π/8, and CNOT quantum logic gates, foundational to the development of dye-based quantum computing. We highlight 2/3D supramolecular supports, like proteins and DNA can achieve desired exciton behavior. Further outcomes from this study was a set of new gates, accounting for circularly- and linearly-polarized light, generating imaginary coupling interactions, which serve as a novel control of exciton populations crucial for the implementation of 2-qubit Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm, a key milestone towards full quantum computation. Whilst we focus on dye molecules on dNA , this work broadly lays the blueprint for any exciton-host system to achieve quantum circuitry.

In building synthetic quantum circuits, we assessed how an arbitrary 2/3D DNA scaffold impacts the properties of exciton components, specifically cyanine dyes organized on DNA with single molecule spatial addressability. We varied DNA structures, from a single duplex to a more rigid double-crossover (DX) tile hosting two bound double-helices using synthetic DNA chemistry for precise dye placement. Our outcomes showed that structural rigidity inversely correlated with efficiency in exciton transport, with more complex DX structures exhibiting enhanced efficiency. Additionally, we utilized the versatility of DNA to modify complementary strand length, influencing exciton coupling and lifetimes without altering dye structure synthetically. This work provides a structural framework for easily controlling photophysics and enhancing exciton circuit generation in synthetic quantum systems.

Electron spin, generated by an exciton through charge-transfer (CT), presents a potential qubit with a longer lifespan. While control over excitonic processes, like energy transport, on DNA has been established, interdye CT control has not been demonstrated. By customizing both long-range excitonic and short-range CT couplings of squaraine dyes on DNA, we achieved control over CT processes, breaking symmetry and enabling programmable evolution of excitonic states—a milestone not previously reached with these dyes. This breakthrough, achieved through specific DNA nanotechnology motifs, has broad implications for creating designer spin materials for applications in light harvesting and spin-based computational readout and another functional handle in the field's repertoire of quantum circuit design.

In the pursuit of building practical quantum computation, we address the challenge of effectively controlling individual spins within densely packed quantum memory registers on programmable photonic integrated circuits (PICs). Our approach incorporated multiple diamond color center spins into a cryogenically compatible, high-speed PIC platform. The outcomes of our design allowed selective manipulation of individual spin qubits through tunable magnetic fields and controlled qubits by pulse shaping. This combination of localized optical control and targeted spin manipulation establishes the foundation for scalable quantum networks on both intrachip and interchip platforms. Additionally, our innovative outcomes extend to other materials, such as nitrogen vacancy (NV)-centers in nanodiamonds, demonstrating the broad utility of the proposed method for generating large cluster states efficiently with any atomic or atom-like systems in quantum information processing.

Our synthetic platform for room-temperature quantum sensing and computation, utilizing biological materials, stands out from existing quantum computation platforms. It enables the creation of arbitrary 2/3D circuits with precise exciton delocalization and transport properties. With our DNA insertion of exciton-active units, featuring unparalleled single-molecule addressability, this biological platform can be seamlessly integrated into biological systems, fostering massively parallel sensing and computation. Moreover, it offers the potential for hybrid qubit devices through assembly with other materials, such as established 2D inorganic materials, amplifying its impact on quantum information processing. The tools outlined in this project could revolutionize research across quantum physics, materials science, engineering, and computer science.
